H0.text: Volcanic island arcs are the features that most likely form when crustal plates pull apart from one another.

H1.text: Strikeâ€‘slip faults are most likely formed when crustal plates pull apart from one another.

H2.text: Oceanic trenches are formed by crustal plates that pull apart from one another.

H3.text: Rift zones are formed by crustal plates that pull apart from one another.

A4.text: Rift zones are primarily caused by internal and gravitational stresses generated by magma emplacement within and across various regions of the volcano.

A5.text: At the onset of rifting, the upper part of the lithosphere starts to extend on a series of initially unconnected normal faults, leading to the development of isolated basins.

A6.text: Rifting may lead to continental breakup and formation of oceanic basins. Successful rifting leads to seafloor spreading along a mid-oceanic ridge and a set of conjugate margins separated by an oceanic basin.
